title: Kitchen Ventilation
legalBasis: Royal Decree 486/1997 on workplace safety and health conditions; RITE (Royal Decree 1027/2007) — Thermal Installations Regulation; Law 31/1995 on Occupational Risk Prevention; Royal Decree 1215/1997 on work equipment safety; Royal Decree 640/2006 on food hygiene
summary:
Adequate kitchen ventilation is essential for worker health, safety, and comfort, as well as food safety and regulatory compliance. Commercial kitchens generate enormous amounts of heat, steam, cooking fumes, grease-laden vapors, and combustion byproducts from gas equipment. Without effective ventilation and air quality control, these airborne contaminants create multiple hazards: excessive heat stress causing fatigue and heat-related illness, poor air quality from cooking fumes and combustion products (including carbon monoxide in extreme cases), grease buildup on surfaces creating fire hazards and hygiene problems, steam and condensation causing mold growth and structural damage, and compromised food safety from inadequate temperature and humidity control.

Spanish workplace safety law (Royal Decree 486/1997) establishes specific requirements for ventilation in work environments including air renewal rates, temperature limits, and air quality standards. The RITE (thermal installations regulation) governs ventilation system design and installation. Food safety regulations (Royal Decree 640/2006) require adequate ventilation to control temperature and prevent contamination. Employers must ensure kitchen ventilation systems are properly designed, installed, and maintained. Workers must understand how ventilation systems work, report malfunctions promptly, and follow proper procedures to maximize ventilation effectiveness.

Modern commercial kitchen ventilation typically combines extraction hoods (campanas extractoras) positioned over cooking equipment to capture heat, steam, and fumes at source, exhaust fans removing contaminated air from the kitchen, make-up air systems supplying fresh air to replace extracted air, and filtration systems (particularly grease filters) preventing grease and particulates from entering ductwork where they pose fire hazards. When all components function correctly, the system maintains comfortable working conditions, removes hazardous contaminants, and supports food safety. System failures or inadequate maintenance compromise all these functions, creating serious health and safety risks.
keyPoints: Extraction hoods must be properly sized and positioned over all heat and fume-producing cooking equipment
Ventilation systems must operate continuously during cooking operations; never turn off extraction during use
Grease filters in hoods must be cleaned weekly (or more frequently in high-volume operations) to maintain extraction efficiency
Adequate make-up air must be provided to replace extracted air; inadequate make-up air reduces extraction effectiveness
Report any signs of ventilation malfunction immediately: excessive heat, persistent odors, visible smoke or steam not being captured, or unusual noises from fans
Never block or obstruct hood openings, exhaust vents, or make-up air vents
Annual professional inspection and cleaning of entire ductwork system is mandatory to prevent grease buildup fire hazards
Kitchen ambient temperature should not exceed 26-27°C under normal operations; persistent overheating indicates ventilation problems
Poor ventilation increases risk of heat stress, respiratory problems, and carbon monoxide exposure from gas equipment
Employers must ensure ventilation systems are properly designed, maintained, and operated to protect worker health

sections.heading: 1. Legal Requirements and Standards
sections.content:
Spanish law establishes multiple overlapping requirements for kitchen ventilation arising from workplace safety, thermal installation regulation, and food hygiene legislation. Royal Decree 486/1997 (Article 4) requires that workplaces have sufficient air renewal to avoid indoor air contamination and ensure worker wellbeing. For kitchens, this typically translates to minimum 20-30 air changes per hour depending on cooking volume and equipment. The regulation also establishes maximum workplace temperature limits: 17-27°C for sedentary work, though kitchens often receive some tolerance given heat-generating equipment.

The RITE (Royal Decree 1027/2007) governs design, installation, and maintenance of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems including commercial kitchen ventilation. It requires that ventilation systems be designed by qualified engineers, installed by authorized companies, inspected periodically based on system size and power, and maintained according to established schedules. Food hygiene regulations (Royal Decree 640/2006 implementing EU Regulation 852/2004) require adequate ventilation to control kitchen temperature and humidity for food safety purposes, prevent condensation that could drip onto food, and ensure adequate air quality to prevent food contamination. Employers must comply with all applicable requirements and maintain documentation of system design, installation, and maintenance.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Employer Obligations
subsections.content:
Employers must ensure that ventilation systems are properly designed for the kitchen's size, equipment configuration, and operational intensity. This typically requires professional engineering assessment rather than simply installing generic hoods. Systems must be installed by authorized contractors following all applicable codes and standards. Before beginning operations, systems must be commissioned and tested to verify they meet design specifications and applicable standards. During operations, employers must ensure systems are operated correctly (turned on before cooking begins, left on throughout cooking and for adequate time afterward), maintained per manufacturer and regulatory schedules, and inspected periodically.

Maintenance obligations include regular cleaning of grease filters (typically weekly), professional cleaning of entire ductwork system including fans and exhaust components (annually or more frequently for high-volume operations), prompt repair of any malfunctions, and periodic inspection by qualified technicians to verify continued safe operation. Records of all maintenance, cleaning, and inspections must be maintained and available for labor inspectorate or food safety inspections. Failure to maintain ventilation systems creates multiple liability exposures: occupational health violations if workers suffer heat stress or respiratory problems, fire code violations if grease buildup is found in ductwork, food safety violations if temperature or air quality is inadequate, and potential employer liability for accidents resulting from system failures.

subsections.heading: 1.2 System Design Requirements
subsections.content:
Properly designed kitchen ventilation systems balance extraction (removing contaminated air) with make-up air supply (replacing extracted air with fresh air). Hood design must match the equipment being served: hoods over high-heat equipment like grills and fryers require higher extraction rates than hoods over steamers or low-heat equipment. Hoods should extend beyond the footprint of the equipment to capture rising heat and fumes effectively. Hoods are classified into types based on whether they capture grease (Type I hoods over grills, fryers, ranges) or just steam and heat (Type II hoods over steamers, dishwashers).

Type I hoods require grease filters and typically fire suppression systems. Extraction rates are calculated based on hood size and equipment heat output, typically 150-300 cubic meters per hour per square meter of hood area. Ductwork must be sized appropriately for the required airflow, installed with correct slope for grease drainage, constructed of appropriate materials (typically stainless steel for grease-laden exhaust), and sealed to prevent leaks. Make-up air systems should temper incoming fresh air (heating in winter, cooling in summer) to avoid creating uncomfortable drafts and to maintain overall kitchen comfort. The system's make-up air volume should approximately match extraction volume to maintain slight negative pressure in the kitchen (preventing cooking odors from spreading to dining areas).

subsections.heading: 1.3 Inspection and Enforcement
subsections.content:
Kitchen ventilation is scrutinized by multiple authorities. Labor inspectors verify compliance with workplace safety requirements including adequate air quality and temperature control. Fire safety inspectors check for grease buildup in ductwork, proper fire suppression systems, and compliance with fire codes. Food safety inspectors assess whether ventilation adequately controls kitchen temperature and humidity for food safety. Building and installation inspectors verify compliance with RITE requirements. Insurance inspectors may also assess ventilation systems as part of fire risk evaluation.

Common violations found during inspections include inadequate or absent extraction hoods over cooking equipment, hoods that are undersized for the equipment they serve, grease filters not cleaned regularly (evidenced by heavy grease accumulation), ductwork with dangerous grease buildup posing fire risk, ventilation systems not operated during cooking (workers report systems are noisy or create drafts, so they turn them off), and inadequate make-up air causing excessive negative pressure. Violations can result in improvement orders requiring system upgrades, fines for workplace safety or food hygiene violations, prohibition orders temporarily closing the kitchen until deficiencies are corrected, and in cases of serious fire safety violations, criminal liability. Maintaining compliant, well-functioning ventilation systems avoids these consequences.

sections.heading: 2. How Kitchen Ventilation Systems Work
sections.content:
Understanding ventilation system components and operation helps workers use systems effectively and recognize when they are malfunctioning. The typical commercial kitchen ventilation system has several interconnected components. Extraction hoods (campanas extractoras) are positioned over cooking equipment to capture heat, steam, and fumes at source before they spread throughout the kitchen. The hood contains grease filters that trap grease particles preventing them from entering ductwork. A fan (usually mounted on the roof or exterior wall) draws air through the hood and filters, then expels it outdoors. Ductwork connects the hood to the fan, conveying the extracted air outside.

Make-up air systems supply fresh air to replace the large volume of air extracted by the hoods. Without adequate make-up air, the kitchen becomes highly negatively pressurized, which reduces hood extraction efficiency, creates uncomfortable drafts when doors are opened, can cause backdrafting of combustion equipment (gas appliances), and makes the kitchen uncomfortably hot as extraction effectiveness declines. In well-designed systems, make-up air is supplied through dedicated vents (often in the ceiling) and is tempered to avoid blasting cold or hot air directly onto workers. Some systems integrate heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) to maintain comfortable temperatures throughout the year.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Extraction Hoods and Capture Efficiency
subsections.content:
Extraction hoods work by creating a flow of air that captures rising heat, steam, and fumes before they escape into the general kitchen atmosphere. The hood's 'capture efficiency' depends on several factors: hood size (must extend beyond equipment), hood height (typically 180-210cm above floor for main hoods), distance from equipment (hoods should be as close as practical to cooking surfaces), extraction airflow rate (measured in cubic meters per hour), and air velocity at the hood face. Properly sized hoods with adequate airflow should capture essentially all rising contaminants.

Hood types vary by application. Wall-mounted or wall canopy hoods attach to walls behind equipment rows and require lower airflow rates than island hoods since the wall provides a barrier on one side. Island hoods are positioned over equipment in the center of the kitchen and require higher extraction rates since contaminants can escape on all sides. Backshelf or proximity hoods are low-profile hoods mounted very close to cooking surfaces (like immediately behind fryer vats), using high-velocity air movement to capture fumes with less total airflow than conventional hoods. Each hood type has design requirements ensuring adequate capture. Workers should understand which hood type serves their work area and what proper operation looks like.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Grease Filters and Fire Safety
subsections.content:
Grease filters (typically stainless steel baffle filters or mesh filters) are installed in the hood to trap grease particles from cooking fumes. These filters serve critical fire safety functions: they prevent grease from accumulating in ductwork where it could ignite causing catastrophic duct fires, they protect the fan from grease contamination which could cause mechanical failure, and they improve indoor air quality by removing airborne grease particles. However, filters only work if kept clean. Grease-saturated filters have severely reduced effectiveness and actually increase fire risk.

Grease filters must be cleaned regularly — typically weekly in normal operations, daily in very high-volume kitchens with extensive frying or grilling. Cleaning involves removing filters from the hood, soaking or washing in degreasing solution or commercial dishwashers, rinsing thoroughly, and drying before reinstalling. Many kitchens maintain duplicate filter sets allowing continuous operation while one set is being cleaned. Filters should be inspected during cleaning for damage; bent baffles or torn mesh compromise filtration effectiveness. Some modern systems have automated filter cleaning or disposable filters, but most commercial kitchens use washable permanent filters requiring manual cleaning. This cleaning is not optional — it is a critical fire prevention and system performance requirement.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Make-Up Air and Air Balance
subsections.content:
Every cubic meter of air extracted from the kitchen must be replaced or the kitchen becomes increasingly negatively pressurized. Make-up air systems supply fresh outdoor air to balance extraction. In simple systems, make-up air enters passively through open doors, windows, or transfer grills. However, relying on passive make-up air creates problems: uncomfortable drafts when doors open, difficulty opening doors against pressure differential, reduced hood effectiveness as negative pressure reduces ability to extract, and potential backdrafting of gas equipment (gas combustion products drawn back into kitchen instead of venting properly).

Properly designed systems include dedicated make-up air fans supplying conditioned (temperature-controlled) air into the kitchen. Make-up air should be introduced gently without creating uncomfortable drafts, distributed throughout the kitchen (not all in one location), and sufficient in volume to replace approximately 80-90% of extracted air (leaving a slight negative pressure to prevent kitchen odors escaping to dining areas). Tempering of make-up air is important for comfort: outdoor air in summer may be cooled slightly, winter outdoor air should be heated to avoid blasting cold air into the kitchen. Some advanced systems integrate make-up air with the building's overall HVAC, providing heating, cooling, and humidity control. Workers should notice whether make-up air is operating (gentle air movement from ceiling vents or dedicated make-up air units) and report if make-up air seems inadequate (excessive negative pressure, difficult to open doors, reduced hood effectiveness).

sections.heading: 3. Operating Ventilation Systems Properly
sections.content:
Ventilation systems only protect workers when operated correctly. A common error is turning off extraction systems because they are noisy, create drafts, or to save energy. This creates dangerous conditions: rapid heat buildup in the kitchen, accumulation of cooking fumes and combustion products (including carbon monoxide from gas equipment), increased grease deposition on surfaces, and compromised food safety due to temperature exceedances. Systems must operate continuously during all cooking activities and for a period after cooking ends to ensure complete air clearance.

Proper operation procedures should be established and followed consistently. Turn on extraction systems before beginning any cooking (systems need a few minutes to establish proper airflow), leave systems operating continuously throughout cooking operations, adjust extraction speed if systems have variable speed controls (higher speed for high-heat operations like frying and grilling, lower speed adequate for light cooking), ensure make-up air systems are operating simultaneously with extraction, and leave systems operating for at least 15-30 minutes after cooking ends to clear residual fumes and cool the ductwork. These procedures should be part of standard opening and closing routines for the kitchen.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Start-Up and Shutdown Procedures
subsections.content:
Establish clear procedures for starting ventilation at beginning of each shift or cooking session. Designated person (typically opening cook or kitchen manager) should turn on extraction systems before firing up cooking equipment, verify that fans are operating (listen for fan noise, feel airflow at hood face), check that make-up air systems are operating if separately controlled, visually inspect that hood filters are in place and grease drip trays are empty, and observe airflow for a minute or two to ensure system is functioning normally before beginning cooking.

Shutdown procedures are equally important. At end of cooking, turn off heat-producing equipment but leave extraction systems running for 15-30 minutes to clear all fumes and cool ductwork. This prevents grease condensation in ducts (hot grease-laden air cooling in ducts can deposit grease on duct walls) and ensures complete air clearance. After the clearance period, turn off extraction fans. If the kitchen remains occupied for cleaning or preparation, consider leaving ventilation running at low speed for continued air quality. Before leaving for the day, verify that all ventilation equipment is in the correct state (off if kitchen is closed, or low-speed if overnight prep occurs). Never leave extraction fans running unattended for extended periods when the kitchen is unoccupied and cooking equipment is off — this wastes energy and can create security risks by creating noise that might mask intruders.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Adjusting Operation for Cooking Intensity
subsections.content:
Variable-speed ventilation systems allow extraction rates to be adjusted based on cooking intensity. High-speed extraction is necessary during peak cooking periods with multiple pieces of high-heat equipment operating simultaneously, extensive frying or grilling operations producing large amounts of fumes and grease, and particularly hot or smoky cooking processes. Low-speed extraction is adequate during light cooking periods with minimal heat-producing equipment operating, preparation work with minimal cooking, and late shifts or periods with reduced activity.

Adjusting extraction rate appropriately balances worker comfort, energy efficiency, and adequate protection. Running unnecessary high-speed extraction wastes energy (fans consume significant electricity) and can create uncomfortable drafts and noise. However, running insufficient extraction compromises protection and allows heat and fume buildup. Workers should learn to judge appropriate extraction level for current activity and adjust accordingly. Some modern systems have automatic controls that adjust extraction based on temperature sensors or cooking equipment activation, reducing manual intervention requirements. Whether manual or automatic, the fundamental principle is that extraction rate should match cooking activity level.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Dealing with Ventilation Noise and Drafts
subsections.content:
Two common complaints about ventilation systems are noise and uncomfortable drafts. These issues sometimes lead workers to turn off systems, creating dangerous conditions. If ventilation noise is excessive, this may indicate system problems: fan imbalance or bearing wear causing abnormal noise, ductwork vibration from improper mounting or deterioration, inadequate acoustic insulation around fans or in ductwork, or simply an undersized system forced to operate at maximum capacity continuously (properly sized systems should be able to operate at moderate speeds for normal loads, reserving high speeds for peak demands).

Uncomfortable drafts often result from poor make-up air design: make-up air discharged directly onto workers rather than distributed gently, excessive make-up air velocity creating cold blasts in winter or hot blasts in summer, inadequate tempering of make-up air, or uncontrolled make-up air through open doors creating unpredictable air currents. These are design and installation issues that should be addressed through system modification, not by turning off extraction. Report excessive noise or uncomfortable drafts to management as maintenance or design issues requiring professional attention, not as inconveniences to be tolerated by suffering through operation or avoiding by turning systems off. Properly designed and maintained systems should provide adequate extraction without excessive noise or uncomfortable drafts.

sections.heading: 4. Maintenance and Cleaning
sections.content:
Ventilation system effectiveness degrades rapidly without regular maintenance and cleaning. Grease accumulation on filters, in ductwork, and on fan components reduces airflow, increases fire risk, and eventually can cause system failure. Beyond grease, dust and debris accumulation, mechanical wear on fan bearings and motors, deterioration of seals and gaskets, and corrosion from moisture and chemical exposure all compromise system performance over time. Establishing and following rigorous maintenance schedules is essential for system longevity and worker protection.

Maintenance responsibilities are shared between workers (basic daily and weekly tasks), kitchen management (scheduling and verifying professional maintenance), and specialized contractors (deep cleaning and technical maintenance). Workers should understand their role in basic maintenance, recognize signs of system degradation requiring professional attention, and report any observed problems promptly. Management must ensure professional maintenance is scheduled and completed per regulatory and manufacturer requirements, maintain records demonstrating compliance, and address reported problems promptly.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Daily and Weekly Cleaning Tasks
subsections.content:
Daily cleaning tasks typically include wiping down exterior hood surfaces (particularly around the cooking area where grease spatter occurs), emptying grease collection cups or trays attached to filters (these fill with grease drained from filters and must be emptied regularly to prevent overflow), and visually inspecting filters for saturation (if filters appear heavily grease-coated, increase cleaning frequency). These daily tasks take only a few minutes but prevent grease accumulation that becomes much harder to remove over time.

Weekly cleaning includes removal and thorough cleaning of all grease filters. Establish a consistent schedule (e.g., every Sunday after close, or Monday during slow period) and assign responsibility. Remove filters from hood (note their orientation and position for correct reinstallation), soak filters in degreasing solution or run through commercial dishwasher at high temperature, scrub stubborn grease deposits with brush, rinse thoroughly with hot water to remove all chemical residues, allow filters to dry completely (wet filters can drip into food and reduce filtration efficiency), inspect filters for damage during cleaning process, and reinstall filters correctly positioned and fully seated in the hood. Keep records of filter cleaning including date and person responsible; labor and food safety inspectors may request these records.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Professional Deep Cleaning and Inspection
subsections.content:
Regardless of how diligently workers clean accessible components, grease inevitably accumulates in ductwork and on fan components beyond the filters. This accumulated grease is the primary cause of restaurant fires — duct fires are extremely dangerous, spread rapidly, and can destroy entire establishments. To prevent grease buildup, the entire ventilation system must be professionally deep cleaned at least annually, more frequently (quarterly or even monthly) for high-volume operations with extensive grilling and frying.

Professional deep cleaning services disassemble accessible ductwork, clean all interior surfaces using high-pressure hot water or steam and commercial degreasers, clean fan housings and blades, inspect the entire system for damage or deterioration, and reassemble and test the system. They should provide a detailed cleaning report including date of service, areas cleaned, thickness of grease accumulation found, any deficiencies noted, and next recommended cleaning date. This report is critical for demonstrating compliance with fire safety requirements. Some jurisdictions or insurance companies require cleaning by companies certified to specific standards (such as IKECA certification in some contexts). Verify that your cleaning contractor is appropriately qualified and insured.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Troubleshooting Common Problems
subsections.content:
Workers should recognize common ventilation problems and report them for professional attention. Reduced extraction effectiveness (visible smoke or steam not being captured, kitchen feels hotter than usual, lingering cooking odors) may indicate clogged filters, excessive grease buildup in ducts reducing airflow, fan malfunction or slowing, or inadequate make-up air. Unusual noises (rattling, grinding, squealing, excessive vibration) suggest fan bearing wear, fan imbalance, loose ductwork or mounting hardware, or foreign objects in the fan.

Visible grease dripping from hood or ductwork indicates severely saturated filters or grease accumulation in ducts beyond capacity, requiring immediate deep cleaning. Failure of system to start or unexpected shutdowns may result from electrical problems, failed motors or controls, or safety interlocks tripping due to overheating or other faults. Any of these problems should be reported immediately to maintenance or management. Continue operating as safely as possible (reducing cooking intensity if ventilation is compromised) while awaiting repair. In cases of severe ventilation failure, it may be necessary to suspend hot cooking operations until the system is repaired — this decision should be made by management in consultation with maintenance personnel and with consideration of worker safety and food safety requirements.

sections.heading: 5. Health Effects of Poor Ventilation
sections.content:
Inadequate kitchen ventilation creates multiple health risks for workers. Understanding these risks helps workers appreciate the importance of proper ventilation and motivates attention to system operation and maintenance. Short-term effects of poor ventilation include heat stress (excessive core body temperature from working in hot environments), dehydration and electrolyte imbalance (from sweating in hot conditions), respiratory irritation (from cooking fumes, grease particles, and combustion products), eye irritation (from fumes and airborne grease), fatigue and reduced cognitive function (heat and poor air quality impair concentration and decision-making), and increased accident risk (fatigue, discomfort, and reduced cognitive function make errors and injuries more likely).

Long-term health effects from chronic exposure to inadequately ventilated kitchen environments may include respiratory problems (chronic exposure to cooking fumes has been linked to increased risk of respiratory disease), cardiovascular stress (prolonged heat exposure and physically demanding work in hot environments stress the cardiovascular system), and dermatological problems (skin irritation from grease deposition and sweat). While these long-term effects typically require years of exposure, they underscore the importance of maintaining proper ventilation throughout one's career. Employers have legal and ethical obligations to prevent these health effects through adequate ventilation and workplace temperature control.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Heat Stress Recognition and Prevention
subsections.content:
Heat stress occurs when the body's core temperature rises to dangerous levels, typically above 38-39°C. Initial symptoms include heavy sweating, thirst, weakness, fatigue, dizziness, muscle cramps, nausea, and headache. If heat stress progresses to heat exhaustion or heat stroke, symptoms worsen to confusion, loss of coordination, rapid pulse, hot dry skin (sweating may stop in severe cases), and loss of consciousness. Heat stroke is a medical emergency requiring immediate cooling and emergency medical attention.

Preventing heat stress requires multiple measures. Adequate ventilation to control kitchen temperature is the primary control. Additional measures include allowing regular breaks in cooler areas (every 1-2 hours during very hot conditions), ensuring free access to cold drinking water (workers should drink frequently, not wait until thirsty), adjusting work schedules to avoid peak heat hours if possible, allowing time for workers to acclimatize to hot conditions (new workers or workers returning after time off may be more susceptible), monitoring workers for heat stress symptoms, and training all workers to recognize early symptoms in themselves and others. If heat stress symptoms occur, immediate response is critical: move to a cool area, drink cool water, remove excess clothing, apply cool wet cloths to skin, and seek medical attention if symptoms are severe or do not improve rapidly.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Air Quality and Respiratory Health
subsections.content:
Cooking generates numerous airborne contaminants including particulate matter (smoke, grease aerosols), volatile organic compounds (from high-temperature cooking of fats and proteins), aldehydes and other irritant chemicals, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide (from gas combustion), and nitrogen dioxide (from gas burners). Prolonged exposure to these contaminants can cause acute respiratory irritation (coughing, shortness of breath, chest tightness) and potentially contribute to chronic respiratory problems with long-term exposure.

Proper ventilation removes these contaminants before they accumulate to harmful concentrations. Warning signs of inadequate air quality include persistent or worsening respiratory symptoms (coughing, throat irritation, breathing difficulty) especially in multiple workers, visible haze or smoke in the kitchen that is not being captured by hoods, persistent strong odors (properly ventilated kitchens should not have overwhelming cooking odors), and headaches or dizziness (may indicate carbon monoxide or poor overall air quality). If air quality concerns arise, report them immediately. In extreme cases (e.g., suspected carbon monoxide exposure), evacuate the area and summon emergency services. For chronic air quality issues, request air quality testing and ventilation assessment by qualified professionals.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Special Protections for Vulnerable Workers
subsections.content:
Certain workers are more vulnerable to heat stress and air quality problems. Pregnant workers are more susceptible to heat stress and should have work adapted to avoid prolonged exposure to extreme heat. Workers with pre-existing respiratory conditions (asthma, COPD, bronchitis) may experience exacerbation from cooking fumes and should not work in poorly ventilated environments. Workers with cardiovascular conditions may be at increased risk from heat stress and physical exertion in hot environments. Young workers (under 18) have additional protections under Spanish law and may have lower heat tolerance. Older workers may also have reduced heat tolerance.

When vulnerable workers are identified (through health surveillance, self-reporting, or management awareness), employers must conduct specific risk assessments and adapt working conditions. Adaptations may include assigning to positions away from highest heat areas, providing additional breaks in cool environments, ensuring adequate water access, monitoring more frequently for symptoms, and rotating between hot and cooler work areas. Workers should disclose relevant health conditions to occupational health services (confidentially) so appropriate protections can be implemented. Article 26 of Law 31/1995 requires specific protections for pregnant and breastfeeding workers, including transfer to other duties if risks cannot be eliminated.

sections.heading: 6. Worker Rights and Responsibilities
sections.content:
Workers have both rights to adequate ventilation and responsibilities to use systems properly and report problems. Rights include the fundamental right under Article 4.2.d of the Workers' Statute to adequate health and safety protection at work, including proper ventilation and temperature control. Workers are entitled to work environments where temperature is controlled within reasonable limits, air quality is adequate and free from harmful contaminants, and ventilation systems are properly designed, installed, and maintained. Workers have the right to be informed about ventilation system operation and maintenance requirements, trained in how to operate systems correctly, and consulted about ventilation issues and improvements.

Workers also have the right to report ventilation problems without fear of retaliation, refuse work in dangerous conditions (such as extreme heat or air quality that presents serious imminent danger), and request occupational health assessment if experiencing symptoms related to ventilation deficiencies. Correspondingly, workers have responsibilities under Article 29 of Law 31/1995 including using ventilation systems correctly as instructed, cooperating with maintenance procedures (such as providing access for cleaning), reporting defects or malfunctions promptly, and not interfering with or damaging ventilation system components. These rights and responsibilities work together to maintain safe, comfortable kitchen working environments.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Reporting Ventilation Problems
subsections.content:
Workers should report ventilation problems as soon as they are noticed. Use established reporting procedures (notify supervisor, submit maintenance request, record in defect log). Provide specific information about the problem: what is wrong (e.g., 'Hood 2 over fryers not extracting properly, visible smoke escaping'), when it was first noticed, how severe it is (e.g., 'minor problem' vs. 'urgent safety concern'), and any recent changes that might be related (e.g., 'problem started after filter cleaning' or 'coincides with recent ductwork work').

For urgent problems (severe ventilation failure creating dangerous heat or air quality, unusual odors suggesting gas leaks or electrical problems, visible flames or signs of fire in ductwork, system making alarming noises suggesting imminent failure), notify management immediately and may need to suspend operations until the problem is addressed. For less urgent but persistent problems (gradual reduction in extraction effectiveness, increasing noise levels, minor air quality concerns), document the issue and ensure it is logged for professional assessment. Follow up if reported problems are not addressed in a reasonable timeframe. Workers have the right to escalate safety concerns to worker representatives, occupational health services, or labor inspectorate if management does not respond appropriately.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Participating in Maintenance and Improvements
subsections.content:
Workers should cooperate actively with ventilation maintenance procedures. When professional cleaning or maintenance is scheduled, provide access to work areas, answer questions about system operation and problems, observe procedures (learning about the system), and resume work only after confirming systems are functioning properly post-maintenance. Workers often have valuable insights into ventilation system performance that can guide improvements. If you notice problems or have suggestions for improvements (e.g., 'hood over grill station does not capture effectively when we run multiple items,' 'make-up air creates cold draft on pastry station'), communicate these observations to management.

Some employers establish formal consultation processes for workplace improvements including ventilation (particularly workplaces with safety representatives or works councils). Participate in these consultations constructively. If management proposes ventilation system changes, provide feedback based on your direct experience with the work. Good solutions often emerge from collaboration between engineering expertise and worker knowledge. Remember that you and your colleagues will spend entire careers in kitchens; investing effort in proper ventilation protects your long-term health and makes work more comfortable and safer for everyone.

subsections.heading: 6.3 When Ventilation Failures Require Work Stoppage
subsections.content:
In most cases, ventilation problems can be addressed while work continues with some adaptations (reducing cooking intensity, increasing breaks, using additional cooling measures). However, severe ventilation failures may create conditions where continuing work presents serious imminent danger justifying work stoppage. Examples include complete ventilation system failure during high-heat operations creating risk of heat stroke, suspected carbon monoxide accumulation from inadequate ventilation of gas equipment, fire in ductwork requiring system shutdown and repair, or extreme heat making work medically dangerous (kitchen temperatures exceeding 35-40°C for extended periods).

Article 21 of Law 31/1995 grants workers the right to stop work and leave the workplace when they face serious, imminent, and unavoidable danger. This right should be exercised judiciously — it is for genuine emergency situations, not mere inconvenience. If you believe conditions justify work stoppage, inform your supervisor immediately, explain the specific danger, and request that operations cease until the situation is corrected. If management disagrees and you genuinely believe the danger is serious and imminent, you may invoke your Article 21 right, but be prepared to justify this decision (ideally with support from worker representatives or occupational health services). In practice, most ventilation problems can and should be addressed through normal reporting and maintenance channels before reaching the point of work stoppage.

checklists.title: Daily Ventilation System Checks
items: Turn on extraction systems before beginning any cooking operations
Verify that all fans are operating (listen for fan noise, feel airflow at hood face)
Check that make-up air systems are operating if separately controlled
Visually inspect that all hood filters are properly installed and seated
Empty grease collection cups or trays under filters
Wipe down exterior hood surfaces to remove grease spatter
Check for any unusual noises, vibrations, or smells from ventilation system
Verify that kitchen ambient temperature feels normal for current season and cooking intensity
Observe whether cooking fumes and steam are being captured effectively by hoods
Report any problems or unusual observations to supervisor immediately
Leave extraction systems running for 15-30 minutes after cooking ends
Verify systems are in correct state (off or low-speed) when leaving for the day

checklists.title: Weekly Ventilation Maintenance Tasks
items: Schedule dedicated time for filter cleaning (e.g., Sunday evening after close, Monday slow period)
Remove all grease filters from hoods, noting position for correct reinstallation
Soak filters in degreasing solution or run through commercial dishwasher at high temperature
Scrub filters to remove any stubborn grease deposits
Rinse filters thoroughly with hot water to remove all chemical residues
Allow filters to dry completely before reinstalling
Inspect filters for damage (bent baffles, torn mesh) during cleaning; replace if damaged
Reinstall filters correctly positioned and fully seated in hoods
Clean grease collection areas thoroughly
Record filter cleaning in maintenance log (date, person responsible)
Report any excessive grease accumulation or system concerns noted during cleaning

checklists.title: Ventilation Problem Reporting Checklist
items: Identify the specific problem: reduced extraction, unusual noise, excessive heat, odors, etc.
Note when problem was first observed and whether it is worsening
Identify which hood or system component is affected
Assess severity: urgent safety concern, or less urgent ongoing issue
For urgent problems: notify supervisor immediately; may need to suspend operations temporarily
For less urgent problems: submit maintenance request with detailed description
Document the problem in writing (maintenance log, email to management, defect report)
If problem involves suspected carbon monoxide or gas leak, evacuate and call emergency services
Follow up to ensure reported problem is addressed in reasonable timeframe
After repairs, verify system is functioning properly before resuming full operations
If management does not respond appropriately to safety concerns, escalate to worker representatives or labor inspectorate

bestPractices: Make ventilation system activation part of opening routine — turn on extraction before lighting any cooking equipment
Develop a sensitivity to normal kitchen temperature and air quality — you will notice changes indicating problems
Clean filters on a fixed weekly schedule without fail — missing even one week allows significant grease accumulation
During professional deep cleaning, take the opportunity to observe and learn about the complete system
If kitchen feels uncomfortably hot or stuffy, check that ventilation is operating properly before attributing to weather or activity
Treat ventilation maintenance with the same importance as food safety and cleanliness — it protects your health long-term
Advocate for system improvements if you identify recurring ventilation problems — well-designed systems should work reliably
Hydrate consistently throughout shifts in hot kitchen environments — don't wait until you feel thirsty

glossary.Campana Extractora: Extraction hood — overhead device that captures cooking fumes, steam, and heat
glossary.Filtro de Grasas: Grease filter — removable filter in hood that traps grease particles from cooking fumes
glossary.Conducto de Ventilación: Ventilation duct — enclosed channel that conveys extracted air from hood to exterior
glossary.Aire de Compensación: Make-up air — fresh air supplied to replace air extracted by ventilation system
glossary.Ventilador Extractor: Exhaust fan — fan that draws air through hood and expels it outside
glossary.Estrés Térmico: Heat stress — dangerous condition when body core temperature rises due to hot environment
glossary.Calidad del Aire Interior: Indoor air quality — healthfulness and comfort of air inside workplace
glossary.Monóxido de Carbono: Carbon monoxide — toxic colorless odorless gas produced by incomplete combustion
glossary.RITE: Reglamento de Instalaciones Térmicas en Edificios — Spanish regulation governing HVAC system design and installation
glossary.Renovación de Aire: Air renewal or air change — replacement of indoor air with fresh outdoor air, measured in air changes per hour
